Boivin: Jim Rome headlines new all-sports radio in Valley Paola Boivin , azcentral sports 1:53 p.m. MT Feb. 11, 2017 Feb 1, 2012: Radio personality Jim Rome performs on his show at radio row prior to Super Bowl XLVI at Lucas Oil Stadium. (Photo: Matthew Emmons/USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
A new all-sports radio station has muscled its way into the Valley’s already crowded sports airwaves. 
The Fanatic on 1580 AM launches Monday and will feature some familiar local and national names including Jim Rome, who represents the station’s CBS Sports affiliation. 
The mornings will begin with Valley sports radio veterans Kevin Ray and Mike Bauer at 6 a.m., followed by longtime ABC 15 sports anchor Craig Fouhy from 9-10 a.m. 
Rome anchors the next two hours and precedes Jeffry O’Brien, a broadcaster/comedian who will host “The Daily Blender.” 
Another familiar Valley voice, Jeff Dean, goes for an hour at 2 p.m., followed by Mike Muraco, Dan Manucci and Shawn Crespin (formerly on NBC Sports Radio 1060-AM) from 3 to 6 p.m. 
The station also will include content from SB Nation Radio and feature live game broadcasts. 
Shows will simulcast on FM channels 99.1 and 99.3. Broadcast bit 
The Diamondbacks and Arizona Sports 98.7 have agreed to a five-year extension that will keep the team on the station through 2022. 
Greg Schulte will return for his 20th season as play-by-play voice and will be partnered against with analyst Tom Candiotti. Tom Ferrin is back to handling pregame and postgame show duties as well as secondary play-by-play responsibilities. 
MORE: Wildcats a 3 seed in NCAA's first in-season top 16 seeds Hoops there it is 
The local Final Four organizing committee has a cool opportunity for those willing to donate a little time. 
It is closer to reaching its goal of 3,600 volunteers but still need more to help with community and ancillary events before and during the Final Four, scheduled for April 1 and 3. Assistance is needed with hospitality, operations, information centers, transportation and other areas. 
Volunteers must be at least 18 by March 1 and able to work a minimum of three shifts from three to five hours each. 
They'll score swag, including an official 2017 NCAA men’s Final Four polo shirt, hat and drawstring bag, a ticket to Fan Fest and an invitation to the post-Final Four Volunteer Appreciation Party. 
Go to www.phoenixfinalfour.com/volunteer to register and find more information. 
– Grand Canyon will host the State Farm College Slam Dunk and 3-Point Championships on March 29 and 30. The events are held annually in conjunction with the Final Four. 
The competition, which in the past has featured a variety of standouts such as Bobby Hurley, Steve Nash and Jason Terry, will bring together 24 of the nation’s top men’s and women’s college basketball players. Other events include the Match Hot Shot Team Competition and the Shoe Carnival Battle of the Champions. Participants names will be released at a later date. 
Tickets are $15 for adults and $10 for children and can be purchased at CollegeSlam.com. 
BICKLEY: Valley sports are entering a tenuous time following Final Four 
– I wasn’t sure how I would feel about the NCAA selection committee releasing its top 16 teams to date but I enjoyed Saturday’s CBS show. 
Villanova, Kansas, Baylor and Gonzaga were the top four seeds. Arizona was a ninth overall seed, and No. 3 in the Midwest. Oregon was a No. 8 overall. 
The upcoming Pac-12 Tournament in Las Vegas should be meaningful. 
The show was a good way to build excitement for the stretch run. I disagree with those who want more transparency – showing the current whole field and bubble teams, for example – because I like the element of surprise the real selection show delivers. 
- Wednesday was a rough night for college basketball fans in Arizona, especially those who had school the next day. Both Arizona and Arizona State tipped off at 9 p.m. 
Not a fan. 
RELATED: Phoenix Final Four coverage Quote of the day 
“(The reports of a $1.5 million payout to member schools are) in the ballpark. We were hoping for $5 million to $6 million when we were launching. There was never a guarantee, but we were optimistic because we owned it outright.” – Washington State athletic director Bill Moos to the San Francisco Chronicle on the unmet expectations of revenue from Pac-12 Networks. Stat of the day 
$3 million 
The amount estimated that a deal with DirecTV could bring each Pac-12 school per year.
